details.reused_text:
Vadim Krasikov is serving out a life sentence for murder in Germany

FILE ï¿½ Paul Whelan, a former U.S. marine who was arrested for alleged spying, listens to the verdict in a courtroom at the Moscow City Court in Moscow, Russia, June 15, 2020.

The family of Whelan, an American detained in Russia for nearly four years, said Thursday, Dec. 8, 2022, that the Biden administration ï¿½made the right decisionï¿½ to agree to a prisoner exchange that freed WNBA star Brittney Griner but they are ï¿½devastatedï¿½ that Whelan remains behind.

(Sofia Sandurskaya, Moscow News Agency photo via AP, File)

By Natasha Bertrand, Kylie Atwood, Sean Lyngaas and Jennifer Hansler

Russia refused to release Paul Whelan alongside Brittney Griner unless a former colonel from Russiaï¿½s domestic spy organization currently in German custody was also released as part of any prisoner swap, US officials told CNN, even as the US offered up the names of several other Russian prisoners in US custody that they would be willing to trade.

CNN first reported exclusively in August that the Russians had requested that Krasikov be released along with Viktor Bout, a Russian arms dealer who was serving a 25-year sentence in the US, in exchange for Whelan and Griner.
The US made several other offers to the Russians, sources said, to try to get them to agree to include Whelan in the swap.
Among the names floated by the US was Alexander Vinnik, a Russian national extradited to the US in August on allegations of money laundering, hacking and extortion.

Frï¿½dï¿½ric Bï¿½lot, a lawyer who represented Vinnik in France before his extradition to the US, told CNN on Friday that he was not aware of any current discussions between Moscow and Washington over including Vinnik in a potential prisoner swap.
Since Vinnikï¿½s extradition to the US in August, Bï¿½lot has appealed directly to Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov to help secure Vinnikï¿½s release from US custody.

But ultimately, the Russians indicated they would only be willing to trade someone they considered to be a spy ï¿½ Whelan, who was convicted on espionage charges in 2019 ï¿½ for one of Russiaï¿½s own spies: Krasikov.

A senior Biden administration official acknowledged to CNN on Thursday night that the Russian side had repeatedly demanded someone not even in US custody, even as the US made a number of different proposals.

In the end, the Russians kept asking for the same thing that the US could simply not deliver on, the official said

ï¿½We have shown an openness to talk about that which is actually available to us and gotten only in response a demand for something not available to us,ï¿½ the official said, reiterating that the Russians refused what had been offered to secure the release of Whelan.

The family of Whelan, an American detained in Russia for nearly four years, said Thursday, Dec. 8, 2022, that the Biden administration ï¿½made the right decisionï¿½ to agree to a prisoner exchange that freed WNBA star Brittney Griner but they are ï¿½devastatedï¿½ that Whelan remains behind.

(Sofia Sandurskaya, Moscow News Agency photo via AP, File)

By Natasha Bertrand, Kylie Atwood, Sean Lyngaas and Jennifer Hansler

Russia refused to release Paul Whelan alongside Brittney Griner unless a former colonel from Russiaï¿½s domestic spy organization currently in German custody was also released as part of any prisoner swap, US officials told CNN, even as the US offered up the names of several other Russian prisoners in US custody that they would be willing to trade.

CNN first reported exclusively in August that the Russians had requested that Krasikov be released along with Viktor Bout, a Russian arms dealer who was serving a 25-year sentence in the US, in exchange for Whelan and Griner.
The US made several other offers to the Russians, sources said, to try to get them to agree to include Whelan in the swap.

Frï¿½dï¿½ric Bï¿½lot, a lawyer who represented Vinnik in France before his extradition to the US, told CNN on Friday that he was not aware of any current discussions between Moscow and Washington over including Vinnik in a potential prisoner swap.

But ultimately, the Russians indicated they would only be willing to trade someone they considered to be a spy ï¿½ Whelan, who was convicted on espionage charges in 2019 ï¿½ for one of Russiaï¿½s own spies: Krasikov.

A senior Biden administration official acknowledged to CNN on Thursday night that the Russian side had repeatedly demanded someone not even in US custody, even as the US made a number of different proposals.

In the end, the Russians kept asking for the same thing that the US could simply not deliver on, the official said

ï¿½We have shown an openness to talk about that which is actually available to us and gotten only in response a demand for something not available to us,ï¿½ the official said, reiterating that the Russians refused what had been offered to secure the release of Whelan.

Vadim Krasikov is serving out a life sentence for murder in Germany

FILE ï¿½ Paul Whelan, a former U.S. marine who was arrested for alleged spying, listens to the verdict in a courtroom at the Moscow City Court in Moscow, Russia, June 15, 2020.
The US was unable to deliver on the request for the ex-colonel, Vadim Krasikov, because he is serving out a life sentence for murder in Germany.

CNN first reported exclusively in August that the Russians had requested that Krasikov be released along with Viktor Bout, a Russian arms dealer who was serving a 25-year sentence in the US, in exchange for Whelan and Griner.

(Sofia Sandurskaya, Moscow News Agency photo via AP, File)

By Natasha Bertrand, Kylie Atwood, Sean Lyngaas and Jennifer Hansler

Russia refused to release Paul Whelan alongside Brittney Griner unless a former colonel from Russiaï¿½s domestic spy organization currently in German custody was also released as part of any prisoner swap, US officials told CNN, even as the US offered up the names of several other Russian prisoners in US custody that they would be willing to trade.
Among the names floated by the US was Alexander Vinnik, a Russian national extradited to the US in August on allegations of money laundering, hacking and extortion.

Frï¿½dï¿½ric Bï¿½lot, a lawyer who represented Vinnik in France before his extradition to the US, told CNN on Friday that he was not aware of any current discussions between Moscow and Washington over including Vinnik in a potential prisoner swap.
But Bï¿½lot said he could see Vinnik being part of prisoner swap negotiations in the future.
Since Vinnikï¿½s extradition to the US in August, Bï¿½lot has appealed directly to Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov to help secure Vinnikï¿½s release from US custody.
But Bï¿½lot said he could see Vinnik being part of prisoner swap negotiations in the future.
ï¿½They (Vinnik and Whelan) make part of the possible ï¿½candidatesï¿½ for the next swap,ï¿½ Bï¿½lot said in a text message to CNN.

(Sofia Sandurskaya, Moscow News Agency photo via AP, File)

By Natasha Bertrand, Kylie Atwood, Sean Lyngaas and Jennifer Hansler

Russia refused to release Paul Whelan alongside Brittney Griner unless a former colonel from Russiaï¿½s domestic spy organization currently in German custody was also released as part of any prisoner swap, US officials told CNN, even as the US offered up the names of several other Russian prisoners in US custody that they would be willing to trade.

But ultimately, the Russians indicated they would only be willing to trade someone they considered to be a spy ï¿½ Whelan, who was convicted on espionage charges in 2019 ï¿½ for one of Russiaï¿½s own spies: Krasikov.

A senior Biden administration official acknowledged to CNN on Thursday night that the Russian side had repeatedly demanded someone not even in US custody, even as the US made a number of different proposals.

In the end, the Russians kept asking for the same thing that the US could simply not deliver on, the official said

ï¿½We have shown an openness to talk about that which is actually available to us and gotten only in response a demand for something not available to us,ï¿½ the official said, reiterating that the Russians refused what had been offered to secure the release of Whelan.

(Sofia Sandurskaya, Moscow News Agency photo via AP, File)

By Natasha Bertrand, Kylie Atwood, Sean Lyngaas and Jennifer Hansler

Russia refused to release Paul Whelan alongside Brittney Griner unless a former colonel from Russiaï¿½s domestic spy organization currently in German custody was also released as part of any prisoner swap, US officials told CNN, even as the US offered up the names of several other Russian prisoners in US custody that they would be willing to trade.

CNN first reported exclusively in August that the Russians had requested that Krasikov be released along with Viktor Bout, a Russian arms dealer who was serving a 25-year sentence in the US, in exchange for Whelan and Griner.
US officials made quiet inquiries to the Germans about whether they might be willing to include Krasikov in the trade, a senior German government source told CNN earlier this year.
But ultimately, the US was not able to secure Krasikovï¿½s release.
The US made several other offers to the Russians, sources said, to try to get them to agree to include Whelan in the swap.

But ultimately, the Russians indicated they would only be willing to trade someone they considered to be a spy ï¿½ Whelan, who was convicted on espionage charges in 2019 ï¿½ for one of Russiaï¿½s own spies: Krasikov.

A senior Biden administration official acknowledged to CNN on Thursday night that the Russian side had repeatedly demanded someone not even in US custody, even as the US made a number of different proposals.

In the end, the Russians kept asking for the same thing that the US could simply not deliver on, the official said

ï¿½We have shown an openness to talk about that which is actually available to us and gotten only in response a demand for something not available to us,ï¿½ the official said, reiterating that the Russians refused what had been offered to secure the release of Whelan.

The family of Whelan, an American detained in Russia for nearly four years, said Thursday, Dec. 8, 2022, that the Biden administration ï¿½made the right decisionï¿½ to agree to a prisoner exchange that freed WNBA star Brittney Griner but they are ï¿½devastatedï¿½ that Whelan remains behind.

(Sofia Sandurskaya, Moscow News Agency photo via AP, File)

By Natasha Bertrand, Kylie Atwood, Sean Lyngaas and Jennifer Hansler

Russia refused to release Paul Whelan alongside Brittney Griner unless a former colonel from Russiaï¿½s domestic spy organization currently in German custody was also released as part of any prisoner swap, US officials told CNN, even as the US offered up the names of several other Russian prisoners in US custody that they would be willing to trade.

CNN first reported exclusively in August that the Russians had requested that Krasikov be released along with Viktor Bout, a Russian arms dealer who was serving a 25-year sentence in the US, in exchange for Whelan and Griner.
US officials made quiet inquiries to the Germans about whether they might be willing to include Krasikov in the trade, a senior German government source told CNN earlier this year.
But ultimately, the US was not able to secure Krasikovï¿½s release.
The US made several other offers to the Russians, sources said, to try to get them to agree to include Whelan in the swap.

But ultimately, the Russians indicated they would only be willing to trade someone they considered to be a spy ï¿½ Whelan, who was convicted on espionage charges in 2019 ï¿½ for one of Russiaï¿½s own spies: Krasikov.

A senior Biden administration official acknowledged to CNN on Thursday night that the Russian side had repeatedly demanded someone not even in US custody, even as the US made a number of different proposals.

In the end, the Russians kept asking for the same thing that the US could simply not deliver on, the official said

ï¿½We have shown an openness to talk about that which is actually available to us and gotten only in response a demand for something not available to us,ï¿½ the official said, reiterating that the Russians refused what had been offered to secure the release of Whelan.

Vadim Krasikov is serving out a life sentence for murder in Germany

FILE ï¿½ Paul Whelan, a former U.S. marine who was arrested for alleged spying, listens to the verdict in a courtroom at the Moscow City Court in Moscow, Russia, June 15, 2020.
The US was unable to deliver on the request for the ex-colonel, Vadim Krasikov, because he is serving out a life sentence for murder in Germany.

CNN first reported exclusively in August that the Russians had requested that Krasikov be released along with Viktor Bout, a Russian arms dealer who was serving a 25-year sentence in the US, in exchange for Whelan and Griner.

The German government was not willing to seriously consider including Krasikov ï¿½who assassinated a Georgian citizen in broad daylight in Berlin in 2019 ï¿½ in a potential trade, the German source said.

But ultimately, the Russians indicated they would only be willing to trade someone they considered to be a spy ï¿½ Whelan, who was convicted on espionage charges in 2019 ï¿½ for one of Russiaï¿½s own spies: Krasikov.

Frï¿½dï¿½ric Bï¿½lot, a lawyer who represented Vinnik in France before his extradition to the US, told CNN on Friday that he was not aware of any current discussions between Moscow and Washington over including Vinnik in a potential prisoner swap.

But ultimately, the Russians indicated they would only be willing to trade someone they considered to be a spy ï¿½ Whelan, who was convicted on espionage charges in 2019 ï¿½ for one of Russiaï¿½s own spies: Krasikov.

A senior Biden administration official acknowledged to CNN on Thursday night that the Russian side had repeatedly demanded someone not even in US custody, even as the US made a number of different proposals.

In the end, the Russians kept asking for the same thing that the US could simply not deliver on, the official said

ï¿½We have shown an openness to talk about that which is actually available to us and gotten only in response a demand for something not available to us,ï¿½ the official said, reiterating that the Russians refused what had been offered to secure the release of Whelan.
The US was unable to deliver on the request for the ex-colonel, Vadim Krasikov, because he is serving out a life sentence for murder in Germany.

CNN first reported exclusively in August that the Russians had requested that Krasikov be released along with Viktor Bout, a Russian arms dealer who was serving a 25-year sentence in the US, in exchange for Whelan and Griner.

Former Marine Paul Whelan
By Natasha Bertrand, Kylie Atwood, Sean Lyngaas and Jennifer Hansler, CNN

Russia refused to release Paul Whelan alongside Brittney Griner unless a former colonel from Russiaï¿½s domestic spy organization currently in German custody was also released as part of any prisoner swap, US officials told CNN, even as the US offered up the names of several other Russian prisoners in US custody that they would be willing to trade.
Among the names floated by the US was Alexander Vinnik, a Russian national extradited to the US in August on allegations of money laundering, hacking and extortion.

Frï¿½dï¿½ric Bï¿½lot, a lawyer who represented Vinnik in France before his extradition to the US, told CNN on Friday that he was not aware of any current discussions between Moscow and Washington over including Vinnik in a potential prisoner swap.
But Bï¿½lot said he could see Vinnik being part of prisoner swap negotiations in the future.
Since Vinnikï¿½s extradition to the US in August, Bï¿½lot has appealed directly to Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov to help secure Vinnikï¿½s release from US custody.
But Bï¿½lot said he could see Vinnik being part of prisoner swap negotiations in the future.
ï¿½They [Vinnik and Whelan] make part of the possible ï¿½candidatesï¿½ for the next swap,ï¿½ Bï¿½lot said in a text message to CNN.

But ultimately, the Russians indicated they would only be willing to trade someone they considered to be a spy ï¿½ Whelan, who was convicted on espionage charges in 2019 ï¿½ for one of Russiaï¿½s own spies: Krasikov.
